name: Scaramouche
desc: The former sixth of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers, created by Raiden Ei.

customize.text: Illustrations and Emojis
Version 3.1 - King Deshret and the Three Magi
<color=#ffd780>October 21, 2022</color>
Version 3.2 - Akasha Pulses, the Kalpa Flame Rises
<color=#ffd780>November 24, 2022</color>
3rd Anniversary Letter

<color=#ffd780>October 14, 2023</color>
Hello, Travelers! Here are the "3rd Anniversary Letter" Wallpapers for you~ Feel free to save and use them as you like~
Kabukimono

After the Archon War, Inazuma was ruled by two twin sisters, Raiden Makoto and Ei. Makoto was the Archon for the people, and Ei was her shadow warrior, her kagemusha. During the Cataclysm that occurred 500 years ago, Makoto went to Khaenri'ah alone and died there. Her sister found her remaining consciousness and was able to say goodbye to her only in the subspace of Makoto's subconscious. Ei never found out why her sister, who had no combat skills, went to Khaenri'ah alone, but after Makoto's death, she decided that the ideal of "Eternity" could only be achieved by remaining unchangeable herself. Not to succumb to erosion or change her views on eternity, Ei decided to create a sentient puppet that would rule Inazuma. Before Ei began transforming her divine form, she created a prototype puppet using a secret technique to show that such a creation was possible.

Raiden gave this prototype a "heart," but the appearance and intelligence of this trial product were not made in her image, and this puppet, which could cry from birth, was not even given a name. After shedding tears in his sleep, his creator decided that he was too weak and fragile, both as a person and as a tool. At first, Ei was going to simply get rid of him, but she found this too cruel, so she just sealed his power, put him to sleep, and left him in the Shakkei Pavilion along with a golden feather that confirmed his identity. When the puppet woke up, he spent his days vacantly looking at the beauteous scenery within: the flaming maple leaves, the exquisite window lattices. Within that lovely prison, he lost all perception. The betrayal by his mother was the puppet's first betrayal.

It was by accident that a kind-hearted samurai named Katsuragi would enter the pavilion and free the puppet, taking him to Tatarasuna and introducing him to the people who lived there. At that time, the puppet was as naive as a newborn, filled with goodwill and gratitude towards humans. Katsuragi, upon seeing the golden pinion on his person, knew that this puppet must not have been of ordinary stock, yet had his reasons not to mention his place of origin. Thus, he omitted all mention of Shakkei Pavilion, instead claiming falsely that he had found the young man while patrolling Nazuchi Beach, and he made the puppet play along to not expose the lie. Busy, bustling Tatarasuna became the place of many happy memories for the puppet. There, he briefly became a human. The workers at the Tatarasuna forge, Katsuragi, Mikoshi Nagamasa, Niwa, Miyazaki, and many others taught him to read and write, to make fire, cook food, and to forge. He was named "Kabukimono," which referred mostly to those who wore vibrant colors and behaved in a peculiar manner. Although Kabukimono was offered a new name, he liked that people accepted him as a person. The workers became his family, and everyone long remembered the joyful dance that Kabukimono performed with them when Mikoshi Nagamasa forged his great blade. Kabukimono twirled in the dance, light as a feather. One day, Niwa told him, <color=#ffffffd9>"You're not a puppet. You're a human... you're just missing a heart."</color> When Kabukimono saw people with all kinds of hearts: kind, principled, strong, gentle, his greatest dream was to have a heart too.

At that time, Tatarasuna was led by the heir to the Isshin Art, Niwa. Under his leadership, the region became a cozy and welcoming place where people worked, set goals, and their lives were full of meaning. Tatarasuna was originally created to safely use crystal bone marrow. To improve the technology, the authorities invited a special guest from Fontaine, Escher. At first, Niwa was happy to have a mechanic, but soon began to suspect that the strange black smoke, increasing production problems, and the number of accidents were connected to Escher. In addition, people died due to strange filth deposits inside the Mikage Furnace. Although Niwa and the others did not let the truth leak out, they sent people to Narukami for help, but they did not return. They then sent Kabukimono with a golden feather so that he could obtain an audience with the Shogun. While Kabukimono was away, Niwa decided to go to the dangerous area of ​​the forge with Escher's device to cleanse it of filth and told Escher of his suspicions. Since "Escher" had no reason to put on a show anymore, he revealed that he was the Fatui Harbinger,
whose main task was to subvert life inside Inazuma and persuade Kabukimono to side with the Fatui. The Harbinger killed the inspector and gave his heart to the unsuspecting Kabukimono.

When Kabukimono went for the Shogun's help, he did not know that Ei had already handed over the management of the nation to the Guardian of Eternity, a perfect puppet created in her image. Battling winds and storms, the puppet arrived on a small boat at the Tenshukaku residency. But the real Raiden Shogun had long since left to the Plane of Euthymia. After a series of refusals, Kabukimono, in desperation, displayed the golden feather on his person and asked to see Yae Miko instead. At this time, Miko was busy assisting the Guardian, and though she rushed down as soon as she heard this news, she could only meet the distressed Kabukimono briefly. Yet he had no ears for her promises to send people to their aid immediately, and returned in despair, convinced that the Shogunate had forsaken Tatarasuna. Miko kept her word, and soon, ships with help arrived on the shores of Tatarasuna. But the situation of Tatarasuna did not seem tragic at all — on the contrary, most of the people did not even know about the accident. The mechanic Escher said that Niwa had fled with his family for fear of punishment for his malfeasance. Kabukimono, with Niwa's heart, entered the central part of the furnace to collect all the deposits formed during the smelting. The load was enormous, but he survived. He left the furnace completely exhausted and asked Escher, <color=#ffffffd9>"This device seems to have protected me. What's in it?"</color> The mechanic answered, <color=#ffffffd9>"Niwa fled this place for fear of punishment, but he left you a gift. He said it's the one thing that you've been looking for... He took it straight from the chest of one of his innocent servants."</color> The mechanic removed the withered heart from the device as he spoke. And although receiving a heart was his purpose for being, the very reason he existed, this heart didn't contain any blessings, but was instead a sacrifice brimming with selfishness, hypocrisy, cunning, and curses, all wrapped in an amiable husk. But if Kabukimono were to wrench this "heart" out, he would no longer be able to feel anything at all. A heart taken out after a murder should bring misfortune, but it saved him from the polluted sediment. Kabukimono then thought that Niwa had betrayed him completely, but this betrayal helped him survive. Overcome with rage and grief, he threw the heart to the ground and left Tatarasuna without regrets. Having learned that Kabukimono considered the fleeing Niwa his friend, Miko did not dare to disturb him anymore, only sending him back the golden feather.

The third betrayal was that of a little boy with no name, the son of the workers of Tatarasuna. His parents were swordsmiths, but then the manager of the workshop died, and his parents also fell ill with a strange disease that often made them cough up blood. Although the child was ill, his eyes remained clear. He lived alone in a ramshackle hut, where the walls were pierced by the wind and the roof could not protect him from the rain. Seeing his constantly mud-caked face through the gaps in the decrepit wooden door, the Kabukimono felt something twist in his heart, as if some ancient feeling was being re-awakened. As Kabukimono was heading to Inazuma, the boy said to him: "But it's raining really hard right now. They say that the people who left haven't returned!" Unable to find an answer, Kabukimono only smiled at the boy, and thus began their friendship. Having met a child who was as nameless as he was, Kabukimono decided to live with him and take care of the sick boy. Kabukimono brought him fruit and drinking water and helped him wash. As proof of his friendship, the puppet took the boy to the Shakkei Pavilion to show him the place where he once lived. He told him that he had no heart, and the boy told him a story about a tin soldier and a ballerina.

There was a tin soldier who always wanted to be with a beautiful ballerina. But the soldier had no heart, and he could not understand where his feelings came from. One day, his owner didn't want him anymore, and he threw him into a fire. But even engulfed in flames, the soldier did not take his eyes off the ballerina. The next day, people opened the oven and found a tiny heart in the ashes. When Kabukimono said that it was just ashes in the shape of a heart, the child replied that sometimes hearts are born from ashes. One night, Kabukimono left the hut to get some food or household goods. When he returned, the child was lying lifeless. Powerless in the face of death, he broke his promise to Kabukimono. After recovering from the initial shock, Kabukimono felt an incomparable rage. He was alone again. Kabukimono burned the hut, put on his head an old straw hat that had been left by the previous owners, and set out on a long journey. He wandered around the world without any goal. He met many different people along the way, but he no longer considered any of them his fellow travelers.

<color=#ffffffd9>"...Hey! Wh—What's wrong...? Say something!!!</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>...You promised me we could be family! You're no different from Niwa and all the others... You betrayed me too. Haha..."</color>
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Archon War
customize.desc: The war for the divine thrones, declared by the Heavenly Principles. As a result of the Archon War that finished about 2000 years ago, seven rulers of seven nations received the Gnoses, the divine throne, and the title of an Archon.

customize.name: Khaenri'ahn cataclysm
customize.desc: A disaster that occurred 500 years ago. The Abyss was released into Teyvat and Khaenri'ah was destroyed.

customize.name: Beelzebul
customize.desc: The Electro Archon of Inazuma, known as Raiden Ei.

customize.name: Makoto
customize.desc: Raiden Ei's twin sister and the previous Electro Archon, also known as Baal. She died during the Cataclysm 500 years ago.

customize.name: Yae Miko
customize.desc: Lady Guuji of the Grand Narukami Shrine. Also serves as the editor-in-chief of Yae Publishing House. Unimaginable intelligence and cunning are hidden under her beautiful appearance.

customize.name: Il Dottore

customize.name: Katsuragikiri Nagamasa
customize.desc: A blade that was once made in Tatarasuna. Heavy and tough.

customize.text: Kunikuzushi

After three betrayals, Kabukimono realized that humans could not be trusted and that Archons inspired only hatred. He cast aside everything he had and renounced the world. He decided that his heart would never again be defiled by the world's filth, and he erased all human feelings from himself. In Inazuma's traditional theater, there is a certain character known as "Kunikuzushi." Such characters are often schemers and usurpers of nations. At the end of his wanderings, the puppet chose this name as an act of his own will. And as for the name he had once used, even he no longer remembered it.

The art of forging swords has long been a very important part of Inazuman culture, and the Raiden Gokaden were once the top five schools of the forging art in Inazuma, with many members holding important positions in the Yashiro Commission, which manages the country's ceremonial and cultural affairs. The Raiden Gokaden included Amenoma, Futsu, Isshin, Hyakume, and Senju, but of the five schools, only the Amenoma Art still retains its artisan lineage. The descendants of the Isshin Art are also still alive, but the craft has been lost to time. Kaedehara Kazuha's, the descendant of the Isshin Art, grandfather, was dissatisfied with his father's lack of effort. In his youth, he traveled all over Teyvat to find a way to revive the family business, but to no avail. The decline of the Raiden Gokaden happened very quickly: within a few decades, three of the families suffered various misfortunes and disappeared completely. Later, there was speculation that all of these misfortunes stemmed from some background machinations, meaning that someone wanted to wipe out the Raiden Gokaden. However, since not every family of the Raiden Gokaden came to ruin, such explanations were treated as nothing more than a conspiracy theory. Several generations ago, the Isshin Art was tasked with forging an important Goshintou according to an ancient forging diagram. Though all the craftsmen involved were very experienced, the process was still unsuccessful. Every blade that was forged was defective. When the deadline came, the blade still wasn't finished, so the craftsmen all fled and hid for fear of punishment.

It was believed that the Kaedehara Clan and the Yashiro Commission conducted an investigation, and when Kaedehara and the Kamisato Clan's leader eventually tracked down the craftsmen near the seaside, they met fierce resistance and were unable to stop the fugitives from escaping by sea. The Kaedehara Clan was severely punished for the swordsmiths who had escaped, and the family gradually fell into decline. Commissioner Kamisato was injured by the fleeing swordsmiths, which, combined with his advanced age, caused him to pass away shortly thereafter. Previously, the failure to forge the blade was ultimately attributed to a lack of required skill and finesse, but the heir of the Kaedehara Clan, Kazuha, discovered a letter from his great-grandfather. In the letter, Kaedehara Yoshinori told of the persecution of the swordsmiths alongside Commissioner Kamisato. While they were waiting for the culprits on the seashore, a single eccentric stranger appeared, claiming to be the one behind the failed forgings. He threatened to destroy the Raiden Gokaden and easily defeated everyone present. Commissioner Kamisato was seriously injured, and Kaedehara barely escaped death. The stranger saw his face and asked if he had any relation to the Niwa clan. Kaedehara replied that it was his father's family name and that after he disappeared, he was adopted by the Kaedehara family. Upon hearing the answer, the stranger fell silent and then said, <color=#ffffffd9>"Tell her this. My name is Kunikuzushi."</color> He then turned and left. Lord Kamisato chose to keep quiet about the incident, fearing that careless talk might drag others into what might be considered a treasonous crime. Kaedehara Yoshinori owed him a favor, so he agreed to keep it a secret. Although he was deeply ashamed to witness the decline of the Isshin Art, the safety of his children and grandchildren was more important. For Kunikuzushi, the destruction of the Raiden Gokaden was only a desire to take revenge on the sword master, and he abandoned his plans halfway because he lost interest in them. He later said, <color=#ffffffd9>"It was all just a little experiment into human nature."</color> Only many years later, after becoming a Wanderer, Kunikuzushi restored the original diagrams of the Goshintou and sent them to the Yashiro Commission and the remaining Amenoma School.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Kaedehara Kazuha
customize.desc: A wandering samurai from Inazuma who is currently with Liyue's Crux Fleet. A gentle and carefree soul whose heart hides a great many burdens from the past.

customize.name: Ancient Forging Blueprint
customize.desc:
An ancient forging blueprint. The Shogun once ordered the Kaedehara Clan to forge a Goshintou according to it.
After being soaked in water, it becomes clear that some of the text has been blurred — someone tampered with the blueprint, dooming the forging to failure and triggering the tragedy that followed...

customize.text: Scaramouche

A few years after Kabukimono left Tatarasuna, he met
the first Fatuus. By this point, he had stopped calling himself "Kabukimono" and was once again nameless. He had abandoned his desire to become human, and his old name had lost its meaning. He wanted to abandon the false names that mortals had given him, but The Jester managed to convince the puppet: attracted by the mad festivities in Snezhnaya, he agreed to join the Fatui. In Snezhnaya, he was warmly welcomed by a stranger named The Doctor. Puppet-making techniques had their roots in Khaenri'ah, and his nature as a creation of the Electro Archon made him all the more special. The Doctor offered the puppet to become the key reference material for one of his experiments, which had been going on for several decades. As a result, Dottore received the basic technology to create "segments" of himself. In exchange, The Doctor removed the seal from the puppet and then improved his powers. The Fatui continued to call him the "puppet," and so he saw himself also — a puppet, unafraid of death and inexhaustible. On the Tsaritsa's orders, he would lead a company to explore the Abyss, and there he spent much time. More than once, he was wounded, then repaired by The Doctor, and thus he grew stronger, surviving to be wounded again by ever mightier foes. After that, he delivered the results of the Abyss reconnaissance to Snezhnaya, thanks to which he became the number Six among the Eleven Fatui Harbingers. Instead of exploring the Abyss, he was now to constantly be on standby, assisting the clandestine activities of the Fatui across the world. And only then did he consider it possible to accept a new name — "Balladeer." On one of the expeditions, while studying fallen stars, he met with the Traveler for the first time and learned that the sky of Teyvat was fake, and the stars in the sky were not real. Now he had strength, power, and a craving for discord. Chess pieces roll across the board, and assassins sow chaos on the stage. At that moment, he believed that only "Balladeer" was his true name. Scaramouche was known for his cruelty to his subordinates and liked to see expressions of horror and helplessness on people's faces.

One of the tasks of the Harbinger was to organize the Delusion Factory in Inazuma together with another Fatui Harbinger, La Signora, to destabilize the situation in the country and obtain the Electro Gnosis. Like many of his colleagues, he thought that Signora was a hindrance who considered herself invincible and allowed her emotions to get the better of her. At the factory, Scaramouche met the Traveler for the second time, whom he had met once before. The Balladeer confirmed that the Fatui were behind the Vision Hunt Decree declared in Inazuma and that they benefited from the civil war that was destroying the country from the inside. The Traveler was knocked unconscious by the remains of the dead gods used to make the Delusions, and the Guuji of the Grand Narukami Shrine, Yae Miko, an old acquaintance of the Balladeer, came to their aid. Although the Fatui believed that the Gnosis was in the hands of the Shogun, Yae Miko had kept it for four hundred years, and she exchanged it for the Traveler's safety. After receiving the Gnosis, Scaramouche, instead of delivering it to Snezhnaya, went into hiding. Just like four hundred years ago, his main desire was to obtain the "heart," and he finally had it.

After Scaramouche disappeared with the Gnosis, Dottore approached him with a proposal to create a new God of Wisdom in Sumeru. After the death of Greater Lord Rukkhadevata during the Cataclysm five hundred years ago, the Sumeru Akademiya locked the new goddess in the Sanctuary of Surasthana and began to rule the country themselves. Although the Akademiya seemed to be thriving at first glance, in reality, Sumeru science had been stagnating since the time of Rukkhadevata. In addition, Irminsul had begun to dry up, and the sages had tried almost every available method, but had not achieved any results. At this time, Dottore, who had once been expelled from the Akademiya, approached them. He brought the Gnosis and said that he would like to use the Akademiya's research environment to create an Archon. First, the Akademiya spent a long time constructing a "divine vessel," which was based on an exquisite humanoid puppet. After that, they harvested dreams via the "Sabzeruz Festival Samsara," maximizing the Akasha's output.

With The Doctor's help, and the Akasha now functioning at maximum efficiency, they were able to use it to extract the power from the Gnosis and convert it into a "divine core." Next, they decided that their new god needed to possess "divine wisdom," so they needed a huge quantity of Divine Canned Knowledge. The Balladeer believed that becoming a god was his destiny, and up until that point, his life had consisted of a series of insignificant actions leading up to that end. He was like a piece of paper, useless in itself, and only meaningful by what was filled in. Even if the Divine Canned Knowledge would destroy Scaramouche's personality, he would not care. By combining the powers of Sumeru's Six Darshans, a new artificial divinity was created for the God of Wisdom, Shouki no Kami, the Prodigal. Scaramouche gained access to Irminsul, and with the Gnosis, he could control the weather in Sumeru. His first follower was a girl from the Akademiya who wanted to establish a connection with Irminsul, but established a connection with a false deity. Since she looked into the consciousness of the Balladeer and saw his past, the Harbinger decided that her appearance marked the beginning of the formation of his divine power, and her reverence would be the foundation of his glory.

When Scaramouche's formation as the new deity was almost complete, the Traveler was able to free the real Dendro Archon. Together, they plunged Shouki no Kami into a cycle of dreams, lasting 168 cycles — exactly the same number of times as the researchers from the Akademiya conducted the "Sabzeruz Festival Samsara." Using the knowledge gained from each defeat and collecting the wisdom of the people of Sumeru, the Traveler and Lesser Lord Kusanali finally defeated Shouki no Kami, and the Dendro Archon took his Electro Gnosis.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Fatui
customize.desc: A Snezhnayan organization that is loyal to the Tsaritsa and has spread out all over the continent. Its Harbingers are on the hunt for the Gnoses.

customize.name: Sumeru Akademiya
customize.desc: The Sumeru organization, which exercises administrative control over the region and educates people.

customize.name: Irminsul
customize.desc: Irminsul can be thought of as a large tree growing downwards rather than upwards, containing all the knowledge and wisdom of the world from ancient times to the present. Ley Lines, like the roots of Irminsul, cross the earth, absorbing the memories of the world.

customize.name: Sabzeruz Festival
customize.desc: A Sumeru festival named after the Goddess of Flowers and celebrating the birthday of the Dendro Archon.

customize.name: Gnosis
customize.desc: Gnoses are internal magical foci that each of The Seven possesses, allowing them to resonate directly with Celestia itself and serving as an emblem of their status. The Gnoses were created from the remains of the Third Descender.

customize.name: Pierro
customize.desc: The first Fatuus, also known as The Jester. He was a royal mage in Khaenri'ah and was cursed with immortality.

customize.name: Il Dottore
customize.desc: The Second of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers, codenamed The Doctor. Had multiple "segments" of himself, nearly all of which he destroyed in a deal with the Dendro Archon.

customize.name: La Signora
customize.desc: The Eighth of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers, also known as The Fair Lady. Her real name is Rosalyne-Kruzchka Lohefalter.

customize.name: Buer
customize.desc: The Dendro Archon of Sumeru.

customize.name: Shouki no Kami, the Prodigal
customize.desc:
Shouki no Kami, as an artificial divinity created using all the might of Sumeru's Six Darshans, has power that rivals that of true gods.
But those of this world who call such a being a "false deity" misunderstand the true meaning of the word.
Shouki no Kami now understands countless things and shoulders unassailable might, and may be said to surpass mortals.
If gods must love mortals, then Shouki no Kami, who grants failure in equal measure to humanity loves them also.
If gods must watch over humanity,
...
...
Then Shouki no Kami who has borne witness to infinite love, hatred, partings, grudges, and maddening anger - thus does he watch over mortals.

"Too much happiness you have had!"
"It has made you foolish. Arrogant. Horrifying in your greed."
"Let this era end!"
"Let the new god announce the defeat of the old."
"Foolish mortal... There is yet time for you to kneel."

customize.text: Wanderer

After his defeat at the hands of Lesser Lord Kusanali, Scaramouche was left unconscious under her care in the Sanctuary of Surasthana. The Fatui Harbingers were not ready to take back the loser, so the Balladeer was no longer needed by them. Before his unsuccessful transformation into the new Archon, the Balladeer gained the ability to communicate with Irminsul. Although he lost the Gnosis, he still had the ability, and Buer made a deal with him and instructed him to conduct research in Irminsul. Because Scaramouche had spent much energy during the last battle, he posed no threat to Sumeru, and under the care of the Traveler, Kusanali sent him to study information about the Descenders. During his research, Scaramouche learned the truth about what happened in Tatarasuna four hundred years ago and how Dottore used him. He learned that Niwa, who had taught him how to live a normal life and treated him like a true friend, had not fled Tatarasuna to escape punishment. In fact, the true culprit had been Escher, The Doctor.

And as for the heart that had been placed within The Balladeer, it had been cut, still warm, from Niwa's breast. With his silver tongue, Escher quickly convinced everyone that the accident in the furnace was the fault of Niwa, the local overseer in Tatarasuna, and that he had fled to escape responsibility for his misdeed. Mikoshi Nagamasa was the next person in charge and would have faced capital punishment if not for the intervention of his loyal samurai retainer, Katsuragi, who willingly took the burden of wrongdoing upon himself. Nagamasa had to wash away the stain on Mikoshi's name, so he drew his beloved blade, Daitatara Nagamasa, from its sheath and struck Katsuragi down in a single blow. Scaramouche wondered if Escher would have done the same to Tatarasuna if Kabukimono had never existed. After fulfilling the deal with Lesser Lord Kusanali, Scaramouche created a barrier to keep him and the Traveler away from the Goddess of Wisdom and asked the Traveler if it was possible to change the past. Although the Traveler did not answer, their silence gave Scaramouche the answer he needed. Hoping to change what happened to his friend in Tatarasuna, the former Harbinger erased himself from Irminsul entirely.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Everything can be set right. It's time to solve this once and for all"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Yes, embrace it, embrace it with this form that shall be obliterated!</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>To ruin with this life, as worthless as flowers and feathers and the dawn dew!</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Farewell, world! The future shall be what it will. Farewell nonetheless!"</color>

Although everyone but the Traveler had forgotten about Scaramouche the next morning, what had actually happened had not changed. According to researchers, more than four centuries ago, there was a catastrophic malfunction in Tatarasuna's furnace. The Armory Officer, Niwa, who was supervising the work, leaped into the furnace along with a swordsmith. The problems were solved, but both died, and the life of the swordsmith's family was destroyed. His orphaned son was left to fend for himself and grew up deeply resentful of the world. In his heart, the whole of Inazuma was culpable in his tragedy. He hated the Almighty Shogun for her apparent indifference toward his father's death, and he hated everyone who had done nothing to try and save him. Powerless and destitute, the only legacy he had to pass on to his children was his hatred. Generation after generation bore this grudge, living in utter misery. A hundred years ago, the head of the family decided that things could not go on like this any longer and made a drastic decision: to take revenge on the Raiden Gokaden. In doing so, he sought to vent his pent-up anger and shake the very foundations of Inazuma's forging industry. Although the head was from the Hyakume Clan, he did not spare even the blacksmiths of his clan. Only the heads of the Kamisato and Kaedehara Clans were able to fight him off, and he died. And although the legend of the Raiden Gokaden changed, Niwa still died, and Scaramouche was unable to rewrite history.

Scaramouche himself did not disappear as well. The memory of his life changed, and he became the Wanderer. After long wanderings, he ended up in Sumeru, where a merchant sheltered him in a cart during a thunderstorm. The Wanderer remained to work for the merchant as an assistant, but he did not even need Mora. In order to tell about what happened to Scaramouche, the Traveler turned to the Goddess of Wisdom for help, although she also did not remember the Balladeer. It turned out that in her personal data, Lesser Lord Kusanali left a note hidden in a secluded corner, which was an allegory for the past.

Although in all other notes the information about the Balladeer or Kabukimono was changed, the goddess recorded this tale in such a way that it remained intact. There once was a lone monster draped in fox fur. The monster found a family of foxes, joined them, and they became friends. The monster lived with the family, day and night, and everyone treated it as one of their own. Once in a while, the monster would take off its fox fur at night, and lament to itself as it gazed at its reflection in the water: <color=#ffffffd9>"I am a monstrosity, yet they are too foolish to see it... I pity them."</color> But the monster soon found solace when another came to live among the foxes who was not their kin: a kitten, carved from the wood of a white tree, who had been abandoned by the humans.

The kitten, too, wished to become a fox, but its tail was too slender and it could not grow a coat of richly colored fur. Yet when the other foxes saw this, they spoke words of comfort to the kitten: <color=#ffffffd9>"Even without a tail and fur like ours, you are still one of us."</color> Furious at this happy resolution, the monster lit a fire on the mountain. The terrified animals panicked as the fire spread. The only way to extinguish the flames was to make a sacrifice. A gray fox stood up and addressed the monster. It said: <color=#ffffffd9>"You are the cleverest among us. Surely you can help us find a way to solve this."</color> The monster smiled, led the fox toward the fire... and murdered it. The gray fox's heart was turned into a beautiful drop of water, clear, spotless, and pure. The monster gave the heart of water to the kitten, telling him: <color=#ffffffd9>"The foxes have decided. You are the one who must be sacrificed. Take this, quench the flames, and die for your fox kin."</color>

The fire was extinguished, but the kitten lived. It left that side of the mountain and found a little bird who had a broken wing. The two promised they would spend their whole lives together, but the little bird did not have long left to live. It passed away soon after. After burying the bird, the kitten left the mountain for good. ...Never again would it cherish a single creature, nor a single blade of grass that stood on that mountain. The kitten spent the nights wandering aimlessly, gnashing its teeth at the moon. How it wished to swallow the moon and devour the moonlight. If the world could only return to darkness, then it would finally be peaceful and content. <color=#ffffffd9>"I will become the new moon, the answer to everything. Then, no one will know that there were once birds, foxes, and cats in this world. And no one can know that they were different."</color>
Upon hearing the tale, the Dendro Archon realized that it was Scaramouche's altered memories, extracted by the Akademiya researchers before the Balladeer's transformation into a deity. She had deliberately left the data behind and stored it so that the Balladeer could obtain it naturally, in order to lure him over to her side. His past experiences made him useful to Sumeru, but she was unwilling to use him as Dottore did. When the Traveler and Paimon met Scaramouche in Sumeru, they took him to the Goddess of Wisdom, and he agreed to learn about his past. When he awoke in the Shakkei Pavilion, he chose the name Wanderer because he was like a plant with no roots. Despite the painful memories, Wanderer agreed to look at them all, regaining a part of his lost identity. Having spent his entire life with an emptiness inside, the Wanderer finally had a chance to find himself by accepting the sins that had disappeared. He did not want to run away from his guilt and punishment, and asked for the cloak of his sins to be returned to him. By restoring his memory, the Wanderer destroyed the personality he had acquired after changing Irminsul, and all the emotions he had discarded returned. Even in the Wanderer's personality, there had always been a longing for something more. Despite his quest as a shugenja, he had never been able to fully comprehend it. The lost memories finally gave him a meaning in life, changed his fate, and put an end to his wanderings. When the Wanderer regained all his previous memories, he agreed to stay with Lesser Lord Kusanali to be useful and valuable.

When the Wanderer finally remembered his true identity, he heard the sound of the wind. He knew not whence it had come, only that it changed direction as if to greet him. On it were scents old and nostalgic — the iron hammer, metals, the furnace, the dust of the earth. In that instant, he beheld his own reflections, each one vivid, each one real, each one him. Cowering in fear, pathetic in his agony, arrogant yet laughable, and they all coalesced into one body. To accept the past is to acknowledge its failings, to recognize that one is naught but a coward who has achieved nothing, who has nothing. But only by doing so could he break free of his shackles and become, once again, that tragic person. In that moment, he knew this: that the appearances of peace and beauty were but an illusion. The real him had never died, no, it lived on deep within his heart. As long as he still had a choice, he would tread the same course no matter how many times he did this over. As he moved like lightning itself, a blazing light came between him and the Everlasting Lord of Arcane Wisdom, blocking its attack. His will and his choice had gained him the eye of the gods. The Vision descended, and caught between bright light and darkness, the glittering ornament seemed almost like an eye on a smiling face, questioning him from afar: Can you, who have desires of such intensity, still be considered a being without a heart?

After Scaramouche erased himself from Irminsul, even his creator, Ei, forgot all about her creation. The Fatui also forgot about him, and it is now believed that the place of the sixth Fatui Harbinger has been empty for several hundred years. One day, he went to Treasures Street to learn how to make toys from the local merchants. The Wanderer spent much time practicing, doing this thing that did not fit his personality. A few days later, his great work was complete — a little man with white clothes and black hair, a waistband tied using a butterfly knot, and a clear, round tear at the corner of his eye. Once upon a time, there was a young fellow who had made this doll in imitation of the Wanderer's past appearance. Shame, then, that he had burned both the doll and his old home to ashes when he left Inazuma. Many years later, he made a similar doll, and it was as if he had met an old friend. The doll was so small and soft to the touch, like a defenseless baby. It took up little space in his sleeves, and if he kept it in his hat, it felt like having a travel companion. <color=#ffffffd9>"From today, you shall wander together with me."</color> He said softly, placing it in his pocket.

customize.name: Fatui
customize.desc: A Snezhnayan organization that is loyal to the Tsaritsa and has spread out all over the continent. Its Harbingers are on the hunt for the Gnoses.

customize.name: Irminsul
customize.desc: Irminsul can be thought of as a large tree growing downwards rather than upwards, containing all the knowledge and wisdom of the world from ancient times to the present. Ley Lines, like the roots of Irminsul, cross the earth, absorbing the memories of the world.

customize.name: Vision
customize.desc: Visions are external magical foci bestowed by Celestia and The Seven upon Allogenes, a small minority of people with strong desires, allowing them to channel a specific elemental power. Every wielder of a Vision is able to attain godhood and ascend to Celestia.

customize.name: Il Dottore
customize.desc: The Second of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers, codenamed The Doctor. Had multiple "segments" of himself, nearly all of which he destroyed in a deal with the Dendro Archon.

customize.name: Buer
customize.desc: The Dendro Archon of Sumeru.

customize.name: Wanderer
customize.desc: A wayfaring figure whose identity is a mystery. He dresses like a mountain ascetic, but he certainly does not act the part.

customize.name: Raiden Shogun
customize.desc: Her Excellency, the Almighty Narukami Ogosho, who promised the people of Inazuma an unchanging Eternity.

customize.text: Voice-Overs

<color=#ffd780>About Kunikuzushi</color>
<color=#ffffff73>He came about as a byproduct of creating the Shogun. Perhaps it's because I feel like I owe him something, but I do not wish to assert control over him.</color>
Character Story

<color=#ffd780>Character Story 2</color>
<color=#ffffff73>For beings with a perishable form of flesh to pursue Eternity, they must first solve the unavoidable problem of lifespan.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>This limited time troubled Ei greatly, until one day when a mysterious technique came before her eyes as if by a stroke of fate.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Using such techniques, one could create intricate puppets indistinguishable from true life.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>In theory, this puppet could perfectly imitate everything about Ei. It could surpass the limits of her lifespan and defend Inazuma forever. Yet, how could creating a copy of an Archon be a simple affair?</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Ei conducted countless experiments to this effect, discarded a great many failed products, and spent an unimaginable amount of time and resources—</color>
<color=#ffffff73>But at last, by her dogged pursuit and warrior's spirit, she was able to create a flawless puppet.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>The newborn Raiden Shogun sat there silently, listening to Ei speak all about her, "her," and even about them. The future of Inazuma was here, inscribed upon a gorgeous blueprint.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>The automaton had but one question to ask Ei: "There is no turning back from forsaking your form. Do you regret nothing?"</color>
<color=#ffffff73>"Your existence is my answer."</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Then, Ei transferred her consciousness into her blade, and thus was born the Plane of Euthymia.</color>

customize.name: Yae Miko
customize.desc: Lady Guuji of the Grand Narukami Shrine. Also serves as the editor-in-chief of Yae Publishing House. Unimaginable intelligence and cunning are hidden under her beautiful appearance.

customize.text: Voice-Overs

<color=#ffd780>About Kunikuzushi</color>
<color=#ffffff73>I thought it was a disaster waiting to happen at the time, but she insisted that she wasn't going to lift a finger against the object of her own creation. Had I known how things would unfold, I would have simply disposed of it without her knowing. Hmm? What about now? Hehe... Well, we're no longer waiting for the disaster to happen, are we?</color>
Dialogues

<color=#ffd780>About the puppet</color>
<color=#ffffff73>That puppet was built with technology that has been lost to time. Perhaps she, as a god, is the only one privy to the knowledge of its origins...</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Before Ei began modifying her own godly form, she took it upon herself to create a prototype puppet...</color>
<color=#ffffff73>No, the prototype was merely a proof of concept. Its appearance and intellect were not based on Ei. It was a test.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>The original plan was for Ei to simply discard it. But perhaps Ei thought this to be too cruel, because in the end she chose only to seal the power within it.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Later, this puppet wandered Inazuma as an ordinary human male with his own consciousness, until... the Fatui took an interest in him.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Some eccentric geniuses in the ranks of the Fatui made adjustments to the prototype, not only unsealing his power, but very likely rendering him even more formidable than his original specifications.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Mm-hmm. The object of divine creation is the one who has now taken possession of the Gnosis... and the prototype puppet is now known as "The Balladeer."</color>

customize.name: Tartaglia
customize.desc: No. 11 of The Harbingers, also known as "Childe." His name is highly feared on the battlefield.

customize.text: Voice-Overs

<color=#ffd780>About The Balladeer</color>
<color=#ffffff73>After he took the Gnosis, we lost all contact with him. Now comes the task of trying to hunt it down and get it back... I actually don't mind it — it means I get to travel all over. Wonder if I'll run into you somewhere along the way?</color>

customize.name: Nahida
customize.desc: A caged bird secluded within the confines of the Sanctuary of Surasthana who can only see the world in her dreams.

customize.text: Voice-Overs

<color=#ffd780>About The Balladeer</color>
<color=#ffffff73>When he finally achieved the ambition he thought he'd been pursuing all along, was he content at last, or only emptier still? We only yearn for the skies because we cannot fly... Hmm, perhaps he should reflect on this once he has held the sheer emptiness of the skies in his grasp.</color>

Kabukimono
"Kabukimono" referred mostly to those who wore vibrant colors and behaved in a peculiar manner. The puppet was called Kabukimono by the Tatarasuna workers.
Kunikuzushi
In Inazuma's traditional theater, there is a certain character known as "Kunikuzushi." Such characters are often schemers and usurpers of nations. Kabukimono chose this name at the end of his wandering.

customize.name: Gnosis
customize.desc: Gnoses are internal magical foci that each of The Seven possesses, allowing them to resonate directly with Celestia itself and serving as an emblem of their status. The Gnoses were created from the remains of the Third Descender.

customize.name: Il Dottore
customize.desc: The Second of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers, codenamed The Doctor. Had multiple "segments" of himself, nearly all of which he destroyed in a deal with the Dendro Archon.

customize.text: The Fatui Harbinger who tested on Scaramouche to find a technology to create the "segments" of himself. He unlocked the seal on Scaramouche's body, causing his abilities to increase greatly, and later tried to turn the Balladeer into a new Archon.

customize.name: Shouki no Kami, the Prodigal
customize.desc:
Shouki no Kami, as an artificial divinity created using all the might of Sumeru's Six Darshans, has power that rivals that of true gods.
But those of this world who call such a being a "false deity" misunderstand the true meaning of the word.
Shouki no Kami now understands countless things and shoulders unassailable might, and may be said to surpass mortals.
If gods must love mortals, then Shouki no Kami, who grants failure in equal measure to humanity loves them also.
If gods must watch over humanity,
...
...
Then Shouki no Kami who has borne witness to infinite love, hatred, partings, grudges, and maddening anger - thus does he watch over mortals.

"Too much happiness you have had!"
"It has made you foolish. Arrogant. Horrifying in your greed."
"Let this era end!"
"Let the new god announce the defeat of the old."
"Foolish mortal... There is yet time for you to kneel."
